grammar_patterns.explanation: High-scoring IELTS writing combines multiple grammar structures within a single paragraph. This includes complex sentences with subordinating conjunctions, relative clauses for additional detail, passive voice for academic tone, and conditionals for speculation. The key is integrating these naturally rather than forcing them awkwardly.
grammar_patterns.formula: Complex sentence + Relative clause + Passive voice + Conditional (within one paragraph)

examples.en: Although renewable energy sources are becoming more affordable, many developing nations, which lack the necessary infrastructure, still rely heavily on fossil fuels. If greater international funding were provided, these countries would be able to transition to cleaner energy more rapidly.
examples.id: Meskipun sumber energi terbarukan menjadi lebih terjangkau, banyak negara berkembang, yang tidak memiliki infrastruktur yang diperlukan, masih sangat bergantung pada bahan bakar fosil. Jika pendanaan internasional yang lebih besar diberikan, negara-negara ini akan dapat beralih ke energi bersih lebih cepat.

grammar_patterns.tip: When reviewing practice essays, highlight each grammar structure in a different color to visualize your grammatical range at a glance.

grammar_patterns.title: Cleft Sentences for Emphasis
grammar_patterns.explanation: Cleft sentences restructure a simple sentence to emphasize a particular element using 'It is/was... that/who' or 'What... is/was.' They are effective in IELTS for highlighting your key argument or the most important factor in a discussion. This structure demonstrates advanced grammatical control.
grammar_patterns.formula: It is/was + emphasized element + that/who + rest of clause OR What + subject + verb + is/was + emphasized element

examples.en: It is education that holds the key to reducing social inequality in developing nations.
examples.id: Pendidikanlah yang memegang kunci untuk mengurangi ketidaksetaraan sosial di negara-negara berkembang.

examples.en: What many experts fail to consider is the long-term economic impact of environmental degradation.
examples.id: Apa yang gagal dipertimbangkan oleh banyak ahli adalah dampak ekonomi jangka panjang dari degradasi lingkungan.

grammar_patterns.tip: Use one cleft sentence per essay to emphasize your strongest argument. Overuse diminishes the impact.

sections.title: What Is the TOEFL iBT?
sections.body:
The TOEFL iBT (Internet-Based Test) is a standardized English proficiency exam developed by ETS (Educational Testing Service). It is accepted by over 12,000 universities and institutions in more than 160 countries, making it one of the most widely recognized English tests in the world. The test measures your ability to use and understand English at the university level.

The TOEFL iBT is delivered entirely on a computer at authorized test centers or at home via the TOEFL iBT Home Edition. The test takes approximately 2 hours to complete and evaluates all four language skills: reading, listening, speaking, and writing.

sections.title: Test Sections Overview
sections.body:
The TOEFL iBT consists of four sections. The Reading section presents 2 academic passages with 10 questions each, lasting 35 minutes. The Listening section includes 3 lectures and 2 conversations with a total of 28 questions, lasting 36 minutes.

The Speaking section has 4 tasks (1 independent and 3 integrated) and lasts 16 minutes. The Writing section has 2 tasks (1 integrated and 1 independent, now called "Writing for an Academic Discussion") and lasts 29 minutes. There is no break between sections in the current format.

sections.title: Score Range
sections.body:
Each section is scored on a scale of 0 to 30, giving a total possible score of 120. Most competitive universities require scores between 80 and 100, while top-tier programs may require 100 or above. Your scores are valid for two years from the test date.

ETS also provides "MyBest Scores," which combine your highest section scores from all valid test dates within the past two years. Many institutions now accept MyBest Scores, giving you the advantage of multiple attempts.

sections.title: Important Tip
sections.body: Familiarize yourself with the computer-based format before test day. ETS provides free practice tests and interactive tools on their website. Practicing with a mouse, keyboard, and headset will help you feel comfortable during the actual exam. Time management is critical since each section is strictly timed.

key_points.detail: Reading (35 min), Listening (36 min), Speaking (16 min), Writing (29 min)
Each section scored 0-30; most universities require 80-100+
Taken at test centers or at home via TOEFL iBT Home Edition
ETS combines your highest section scores across multiple test dates

sections.title: How the TOEFL iBT Is Scored
sections.body:
Each of the four sections (Reading, Listening, Speaking, Writing) is scored on a scale of 0 to 30. The Reading and Listening sections are scored by computer based on the number of correct answers. Raw scores are converted to scaled scores using statistical equating methods to ensure fairness across different test versions.

The Speaking section is scored by a combination of AI scoring and human raters on a scale of 0-4 for each task, then converted to a 0-30 scale. The Writing section uses a similar approach, with both automated scoring (e-rater) and human raters evaluating each task on a 0-5 scale.

sections.title: Understanding Score Levels
sections.body:
ETS defines proficiency levels for each section. For Reading: Advanced (24-30), High-Intermediate (18-23), Low-Intermediate (4-17), Below Low-Intermediate (0-3). For Listening: Advanced (22-30), High-Intermediate (17-21), Low-Intermediate (9-16), Below Low-Intermediate (0-8).

For Speaking: Advanced (25-30), High-Intermediate (20-24), Low-Intermediate (16-19), Basic (10-15). For Writing: Advanced (24-30), High-Intermediate (17-23), Low-Intermediate (13-16), Basic (7-12). Understanding these levels helps you identify which sections need the most improvement.

sections.title: Setting Your Score Goals
sections.body:
Your target score depends on your purpose. For undergraduate admission, most universities require 60-80. For graduate programs, 80-100 is typical. Top universities like MIT, Stanford, and Harvard often require 100+. Some programs set minimum section scores, such as a minimum of 22 in Speaking for teaching assistantships.

Research your target institutions early and note both total and section score requirements. If an institution accepts MyBest Scores, plan multiple test attempts strategically to maximize each section score.

sections.title: Score Reports and Sending Scores
sections.body: Scores are available approximately 4-8 days after the test. Your registration fee includes up to 4 free score reports sent to institutions if you select them before the test. Additional score reports cost $20 each. You can also cancel scores within 48 hours if you feel the test did not go well, though this should be used cautiously.

key_points.detail: Total score range is 0-120; each section weighted equally
Reading/Listening scored by computer; Speaking/Writing use AI + human raters
Research institution requirements including minimum section scores
Results available in 4-8 days; 4 free score reports included

sections.title: Time Management Across Sections
sections.body:
Effective time management is crucial for TOEFL success. In Reading, you have approximately 1 minute 45 seconds per question. In Listening, questions appear after each audio clip, so pace yourself through note-taking. Speaking tasks have strict preparation and response times (15-30 seconds prep, 45-60 seconds response).

For Writing, allocate your time wisely: in the Integrated task, spend 2-3 minutes planning and 17-18 minutes writing. For the Academic Discussion task, use 2 minutes to read and plan, then 8 minutes to write your response. Always leave 1-2 minutes for review.

sections.title: Building Stamina and Focus
sections.body:
The TOEFL iBT is a 2-hour test with no breaks. Mental stamina is just as important as English proficiency. Practice taking full-length timed tests to build endurance. Simulate real test conditions by working in a quiet room with no distractions.

Stay hydrated and eat a balanced meal before the test. During the exam, if you feel your focus slipping, take a few deep breaths and refocus. Every question counts equally, so maintain consistent effort throughout all sections.

sections.title: Process of Elimination
sections.body:
For multiple-choice questions in Reading and Listening, use the process of elimination to improve your accuracy. First, identify and discard answers that are clearly wrong or contradict the passage. Then compare remaining options carefully against the source material.

Look out for common trap answers: options that use words from the passage but change the meaning, options that are true but do not answer the specific question, and options that are too extreme (using words like "always," "never," or "all"). The correct answer is usually moderate and directly supported by the text.

sections.title: Note-Taking Is Essential
sections.body:
You are allowed to take notes on scratch paper during the entire test. Effective note-taking is especially critical for Listening, Speaking, and Writing sections. Develop a shorthand system using abbreviations and symbols to capture key information quickly. Focus on main ideas, supporting details, and the relationships between them.

Do not try to write everything down. Instead, listen for signal words like "however," "for example," and "the main point is" to identify the most important information.

key_points.detail: Know the time limits for each section and pace yourself accordingly
Practice full-length tests to prepare for the 2-hour exam with no breaks
Use process of elimination for multiple-choice; watch for trap answers
Use abbreviations and symbols; focus on main ideas and signal words

sections.title: How to Register
sections.body:
Register for the TOEFL iBT through the ETS website (ets.org/toefl). You will need to create an ETS account, select a test date and location, and pay the registration fee (approximately $200-$300 depending on your country). Registration is available up to 7 days before the test, but popular dates fill up quickly.

You can also choose the TOEFL iBT Home Edition, which allows you to take the test at home using your own computer with a human proctor monitoring via camera. Both versions are identical in content, scoring, and acceptance by institutions.

sections.title: What to Bring on Test Day
sections.body:
Bring a valid, unexpired identification document (passport for international test-takers). Your name on the ID must exactly match the name on your registration. Arrive at the test center at least 30 minutes early for check-in procedures including photo and signature capture.

You are not allowed to bring personal items into the testing room, including phones, watches, food, or drinks. The test center provides scratch paper and pencils for note-taking. If taking the Home Edition, ensure your room meets the requirements: clear desk, closed door, no other people present.

sections.title: During the Test
sections.body:
The test begins with a microphone check for the Speaking section. Speak clearly and at a normal volume during this check. Each section starts with directions on screen; read them carefully even if you have practiced before.

If you experience technical difficulties, raise your hand to alert a proctor immediately. Do not try to fix issues yourself. Stay calm and focused throughout the test. Remember that you cannot go back to previous questions in the Listening section, so answer each question before moving on.

sections.title: After the Test
sections.body:
At the end of the test, you will see your unofficial Reading and Listening scores immediately. You then choose whether to report or cancel your scores. Unless your performance was drastically below expectations, it is generally better to report scores since you can use MyBest Scores later.

Official scores are available online within 4-8 days. Review your score report carefully and identify areas for improvement if you plan to retake the test. There is no limit to how many times you can take the TOEFL, but you must wait at least 3 days between attempts.

key_points.detail: Sign up at ets.org/toefl; popular test dates fill up quickly
Name must exactly match your registration; arrive 30 minutes early
Same test taken at home with a human proctor via camera
Reading and Listening scores shown right after the test

sections.title: What Are Main Idea Questions?
sections.body:
Main idea questions ask you to identify the central topic or primary purpose of a passage. They typically appear as the first question for each passage and use phrases like "What is the passage mainly about?" or "The primary purpose of the passage is to..." These questions test your ability to understand the overall argument rather than specific details.

To find the main idea, pay attention to the title (if given), the first and last paragraphs, and the topic sentences of each paragraph. The correct answer should be broad enough to cover the entire passage but specific enough to distinguish it from other possible topics.

sections.title: Purpose Questions
sections.body:
Purpose questions ask why the author wrote the passage or why specific information is included. They use phrasing like "Why does the author mention...?" or "The author discusses X in order to..." These questions require you to understand the author's intent, not just the content.

Common purposes include: to compare or contrast ideas, to provide an example or illustration, to support a claim with evidence, to introduce a counterargument, or to define a concept. Always consider what role the mentioned detail plays in the larger argument of the passage.

sections.title: Strategy: Read the First and Last Sentences
sections.body:
Academic passages typically follow a predictable structure. The introduction states the main topic, body paragraphs develop supporting points, and the conclusion summarizes or extends the argument. Reading the first sentence of each paragraph gives you a roadmap of the passage structure.

When answering main idea questions, eliminate answers that are too narrow (covering only one paragraph) or too broad (going beyond what the passage discusses). The correct answer captures the essence of all paragraphs together.

key_points.detail: The answer should cover the entire passage, not just one paragraph
Ask yourself why the author included specific information
First sentences of paragraphs reveal the passage structure

key_points.text: Avoid too narrow or too broad
key_points.detail: Eliminate answers that cover only part of the passage or go beyond it

sections.title: Understanding Vocabulary Questions
sections.body:
Vocabulary-in-context questions ask you to determine the meaning of a word or phrase as it is used in the passage. The question format is usually: "The word X in paragraph Y is closest in meaning to..." These questions appear 2-3 times per passage and test your ability to use context clues rather than memorized definitions.

Many English words have multiple meanings. The TOEFL often tests less common meanings of familiar words. For example, "plant" could mean a factory rather than a living organism, depending on context. Always re-read the sentence containing the target word before choosing your answer.

sections.title: Using Context Clues
sections.body:
Context clues are hints in the surrounding text that help you determine a word's meaning. Look for definition clues (the author explains the word directly), synonym clues (a similar word is used nearby), antonym clues (an opposite word with contrasting signal words like "unlike" or "however"), and example clues (specific instances that illustrate the meaning).

Another powerful technique is substitution: replace the target word with each answer choice and see which one maintains the original meaning of the sentence. The correct answer should fit grammatically and logically in the original context.

sections.title: Building Your Academic Vocabulary
sections.body:
While context clues are essential, having a strong vocabulary base makes these questions much easier. Focus on learning the Academic Word List (AWL), which contains the most frequently used words in academic texts. Study word roots, prefixes, and suffixes to decode unfamiliar words during the test.

Practice reading academic articles from fields like biology, history, psychology, and geology, as these are common TOEFL topics. When you encounter unfamiliar words, try to guess their meaning from context before looking them up. This builds the exact skill tested on the TOEFL.

key_points.detail: The question tests how a word is used in that specific passage
Common words often have less familiar meanings in academic contexts
Plug each answer choice into the original sentence to test the fit
The Academic Word List covers the most common words in TOEFL passages

sections.title: What Are Inference Questions?
sections.body:
Inference questions ask you to draw a logical conclusion based on information stated in the passage. They use phrases like "What can be inferred from paragraph X?" or "The author implies that..." or "It can be concluded that..." The answer is never directly stated in the text but must be logically supported by it.

Think of inference as reading between the lines. The passage provides evidence, and you must identify what that evidence logically suggests. The correct answer will be a small logical step from what is stated, not a large leap or assumption.

sections.title: How to Approach Inference Questions
sections.body:
First, identify the specific paragraph or sentences the question refers to. Re-read that section carefully. Then consider what must be true based on the information given. Avoid answers that require outside knowledge or go significantly beyond what the passage supports.

A useful strategy is to ask yourself: "If the passage statements are true, which answer choice MUST also be true?" Eliminate choices that could be true but are not supported by the passage, and choices that contradict any information in the passage.

sections.title: Common Traps in Inference Questions
sections.body:
The most common trap is choosing an answer that is explicitly stated in the passage. Remember, inferences are conclusions drawn from the text, not restatements of it. Another trap is selecting an answer that seems reasonable based on general knowledge but is not supported by the specific passage.

Also watch for answers that are too extreme. If the passage says "many scientists believe," an inference that "all scientists agree" would be too strong. The correct inference usually stays close to the tone and scope of the original text.

key_points.detail: The answer must be logically concluded from passage evidence
Good inferences stay close to what the text says, not large leaps
If the answer is directly in the passage, it is not an inference
Correct inferences match the tone and scope of the passage

sections.title: Understanding Rhetorical Purpose Questions
sections.body:
Rhetorical purpose questions ask why an author includes a specific piece of information, example, or detail. They are phrased as: "Why does the author mention X?" or "The author uses the example of X in order to..." or "What is the function of paragraph 3?" These questions test your understanding of how an argument is constructed.

Unlike factual questions that ask what the passage says, rhetorical purpose questions ask how and why the passage says it. You need to understand the relationship between a detail and the broader argument it supports.

sections.title: Common Rhetorical Purposes
sections.body:
Authors use various rhetorical strategies in academic writing. The most common purposes tested on TOEFL include: to illustrate a concept with a concrete example, to support a claim with evidence, to compare or contrast two ideas, to introduce a new topic or shift in argument, to challenge or refute an opposing view, and to define a technical term.

When answering, always look at the sentences before and after the highlighted detail. The preceding sentence often states the claim that the detail supports, while the following sentence may draw a conclusion from it.

sections.title: Strategy: Think Like the Author
sections.body:
Put yourself in the author's position and ask: "What point am I trying to make, and how does this detail help me make it?" Every piece of information in an academic passage serves a purpose within the larger argument. Nothing is included randomly.

Be careful not to confuse what a detail says with why it is included. For example, if the passage mentions that "dinosaurs went extinct 66 million years ago," the content is about dinosaur extinction, but the purpose might be to provide a timeline for geological changes discussed in the previous sentence.

key_points.detail: Focus on the author's purpose for including information, not the information itself
Look at sentences before and after the highlighted detail
Illustrate, support, compare, contrast, define, or refute
Ask what point the author is building and how the detail serves it

sections.title: What Are Insert Text Questions?
sections.body:
Insert text questions give you a new sentence and ask you to place it in the correct position within a paragraph. The paragraph shows four possible insertion points marked with black squares. You must choose the position where the sentence fits most logically and cohesively.

These questions appear once per passage and test your understanding of text organization, logical flow, and cohesive devices. The correct position is the one where the new sentence connects smoothly with both the preceding and following sentences.

sections.title: Using Cohesive Devices
sections.body:
The key to solving insert text questions is identifying cohesive devices in the new sentence. Look for pronouns (this, these, it, they) that must refer to something in a preceding sentence. Look for transition words (however, furthermore, for example) that signal the relationship to the previous idea. Look for repeated or synonymous terms that link to nearby sentences.

For instance, if the new sentence begins with "This process," it must follow a sentence that describes a specific process. If it starts with "However," it must follow a sentence that presents a contrasting idea.

sections.title: Step-by-Step Strategy
sections.body:
First, read the new sentence carefully and identify its cohesive devices, topic, and logical role. Second, read the paragraph and understand the flow of ideas. Third, try inserting the sentence at each position mentally and check if it connects logically with the sentences before and after it.

The correct insertion point will create a smooth flow where no information feels out of order or disconnected. If the new sentence introduces an idea, it should come before sentences that elaborate on it. If it provides an example, it should follow the general statement it illustrates.

key_points.detail: Choose among four marked positions to insert a given sentence
Pronouns like 'this' and 'they' must have clear referents in the preceding sentence
Words like 'however' and 'furthermore' indicate the logical relationship
The sentence must connect logically with both the sentence before and after it

sections.title: Understanding Summary Questions
sections.body:
Summary questions (also called prose summary questions) appear as the last question for a passage. You are given an introductory sentence summarizing the passage and must select 3 correct answer choices out of 6 that represent the major ideas of the passage. These questions are worth 2 points (partial credit of 1 point for 2 correct choices).

The correct answers restate the main ideas or major supporting points of the passage. Incorrect choices are either minor details, inaccurate statements, or ideas not discussed in the passage. Focus on the big picture, not small facts.

sections.title: Understanding Table Questions
sections.body:
Table completion questions (also called category chart questions) ask you to sort information into categories presented in a table. You are given answer choices that must be placed into the correct category. These questions test your ability to organize information and understand how ideas relate to different topics or themes.

These questions may be worth 3-4 points depending on the number of answer choices. Like summary questions, partial credit is available. Approach them by first reviewing the categories, then matching each choice based on your understanding of the passage.

sections.title: Strategy for Both Question Types
sections.body:
For summary questions, first re-read the introductory sentence to remind yourself of the passage's main topic. Then evaluate each choice: does it represent a major idea, or just a minor detail? Major ideas are typically discussed across multiple sentences or paragraphs. Minor details like specific dates, individual names, or single examples are usually wrong.

For table questions, make sure you clearly understand what each category represents before sorting. If unsure about a choice, go back to the passage and locate where that information appears. The surrounding context will usually make the correct category clear.

key_points.detail: Select major ideas, not minor details; worth up to 2 points
Organize answer choices into the correct groups; worth 3-4 points
Main points span multiple sentences; details are specific facts or examples
You earn points for each correct choice even if you miss one

sections.title: How to Practice Effectively
sections.body:
Effective TOEFL Reading practice goes beyond simply answering questions. Start by taking a timed practice test under real conditions: 35 minutes for 2 passages with 10 questions each. Use official ETS practice materials whenever possible, as they most accurately reflect the actual test difficulty and question styles.

After completing a practice set, review every question, including the ones you got right. Understand why each correct answer is right and why each wrong answer is wrong. This analysis builds the pattern recognition skills you need on test day.

sections.title: Common Mistakes to Avoid
sections.body:
The biggest mistake is spending too much time on a single question. If you are stuck, make your best guess and move on. You can revisit questions within the Reading section. Another common error is relying on prior knowledge rather than the passage. The TOEFL tests your reading comprehension, so every answer must be supported by the text.

Avoid reading every word of the passage in detail before looking at questions. Instead, skim the passage for structure and main ideas (2-3 minutes), then read specific sections carefully as each question directs you to them.

sections.title: Building a Study Plan
sections.body:
Create a structured study plan that includes daily reading practice. Read academic articles for 30 minutes each day from sources like Scientific American, National Geographic, or university textbooks. Practice identifying main ideas, author purpose, and vocabulary in context as you read.

Take a full practice Reading section once or twice a week. Track your scores and identify question types where you consistently lose points. Focus your study time on improving those weak areas rather than practicing what you already do well.

key_points.detail: 35 minutes for 2 passages; use official ETS materials
Understand why correct answers are right and why wrong ones are wrong
Get the structure in 2-3 minutes, then read details as needed per question
Focus study time on question types where you consistently lose points

sections.title: Lecture Format in TOEFL Listening
sections.body:
The TOEFL Listening section includes 3 lectures, each 3-5 minutes long with 6 questions per lecture. Lectures simulate real university classroom settings and cover academic topics from natural sciences, social sciences, arts, and humanities. Some lectures are monologues by the professor, while others include brief student interactions.

You hear each lecture only once and cannot replay it. Questions appear on screen after the entire lecture finishes. This means you must rely on your notes and memory, making active listening and effective note-taking essential skills.

sections.title: Understanding Lecture Organization
sections.body:
Academic lectures typically follow a predictable structure. The professor introduces the topic, often connecting it to previous class material. Then the main content is presented with supporting details, examples, and explanations. Professors often use signal phrases like "Today we're going to talk about..." or "The key point here is..."

Pay attention to how the professor organizes information. Common organizational patterns include: chronological order, cause and effect, comparison and contrast, classification, and problem-solution. Recognizing the pattern helps you anticipate what comes next and organize your notes.

sections.title: Dealing with Unfamiliar Topics
sections.body:
Do not panic if the lecture topic is unfamiliar. TOEFL lectures are designed so that no specialized prior knowledge is needed. All information necessary to answer the questions is provided within the lecture itself. The professor will explain technical terms and concepts as they arise.

Focus on understanding the relationships between ideas rather than memorizing specific facts. Listen for the professor's attitude and emphasis, as questions often test whether you understood what the professor considers most important or surprising.

key_points.detail: Each lecture is 3-5 minutes long; you hear it only once
All information to answer questions is provided in the lecture
Identify organizational patterns: chronological, cause-effect, comparison
Phrases like 'the key point is' and 'in contrast' highlight important content

sections.title: Conversation Format
sections.body:
The TOEFL Listening section includes 2 conversations, each about 3 minutes long with 5 questions per conversation. Conversations take place in a university setting, typically between a student and a professor, a student and a university staff member, or two students discussing academic or campus-related matters.

Conversations are less formal than lectures and often involve problem-solving or information exchange. One person usually has a problem or question, and the other provides help, advice, or information. Understanding this dynamic helps you follow the conversation's purpose.

sections.title: Common Conversation Scenarios
sections.body:
Typical TOEFL conversations involve scenarios like: a student visiting office hours to discuss an assignment, a student at the registrar's office resolving a scheduling conflict, a student asking a librarian for research help, or a student discussing a campus event with a staff member.

Pay attention to the reason for the conversation (why did the student come?), the main problem or question, the solution or advice given, and any additional complications or decisions that arise. Questions often focus on these elements.

sections.title: Listening for Pragmatic Meaning
sections.body:
Conversation questions often test pragmatic meaning, which is the implied or intended meaning behind what someone says. For example, if a professor says "Have you considered looking at more recent sources?" the pragmatic meaning is a suggestion that the student's current sources are outdated.

Listen for tone of voice, hesitation, emphasis, and indirect language. Questions may ask "What does the professor mean when she says...?" or replay a portion of the conversation and ask about the speaker's intention. These questions require you to go beyond the literal words.

key_points.detail: About 3 minutes each; set in university campus contexts
Why is the student there? What problem needs solving?
Listen for implied meaning, tone, and indirect suggestions
Track how the problem is addressed and what the student decides to do

sections.title: Why Note-Taking Matters
sections.body:
Since you hear each listening passage only once, your notes are your lifeline when answering questions. Good notes capture the main ideas, key details, and the organization of the passage. They do not need to be neat or complete; they just need to trigger your memory of what you heard.

Develop a consistent note-taking system before test day. Practice with various listening materials until your method becomes automatic. The goal is to write quickly without losing focus on what is being said.

sections.title: Effective Note-Taking Techniques
sections.body:
Use abbreviations and symbols to write faster: arrows for cause/effect, plus signs for additions, "ex" for example, "def" for definition, "imp" for important. Create your own shorthand for common academic words. Write key words and phrases, not full sentences.

Organize your notes with indentation to show the relationship between main ideas and supporting details. Start a new line for each new topic or point. Leave space between sections so you can add information if the speaker returns to a previous point.

sections.title: What to Write Down
sections.body:
Focus on capturing: the main topic or thesis, major supporting points, examples and their purpose, definitions of key terms, cause-and-effect relationships, comparisons and contrasts, and the speaker's opinion or attitude. Listen for signal words that indicate important information, such as "the main reason," "for instance," "on the other hand," and "what's interesting is."

Do not try to write everything. If you focus too much on writing, you will miss what comes next. It is better to capture 60% of the content accurately than to attempt 100% and end up with disorganized, incomplete notes.

key_points.detail: They do not need to be complete, just enough to recall key points
Arrows, symbols, and shorthand let you write faster without losing focus
Main ideas, examples, definitions, and speaker attitude are most important
Make your note-taking system automatic through regular practice

sections.title: What Are Detail Questions?
sections.body:
Detail questions ask about specific facts, data, or information explicitly stated in the listening passage. They are phrased as: "According to the professor, what is...?" or "What does the speaker say about...?" or "Which of the following is mentioned in the lecture?" These are the most straightforward question type in the Listening section.

Detail questions test whether you caught specific pieces of information while listening. They do not require interpretation or inference. The answer is something the speaker directly said, though it may be paraphrased in the answer choices.

sections.title: Multiple-Answer Detail Questions
sections.body:
Some detail questions ask you to select two or more correct answers. These are often phrased as: "What are two reasons the professor gives for...?" or "Which TWO of the following are mentioned...?" You must select all correct answers to earn credit.

For these questions, your notes are especially valuable. Review your notes for lists, multiple examples, or sequences of reasons that the speaker provided. If you noted that the professor gave three causes for a phenomenon, you can quickly identify which ones match the answer choices.

sections.title: Avoiding Common Mistakes
sections.body:
The most common mistake is choosing an answer that sounds familiar but distorts what the speaker actually said. Answer choices may use words from the lecture but change the meaning or combine information incorrectly. Always verify that the answer matches what was said, not just what sounds related.

Another mistake is choosing an answer based on your own knowledge rather than the listening passage. Even if an answer choice is factually true in the real world, it is wrong if the speaker did not mention it. Stay focused on what was actually stated in the passage.

key_points.detail: The answer is something the speaker explicitly said, possibly paraphrased
Select all correct choices for full credit on multiple-answer questions
Do not choose answers that sound familiar but distort the original meaning
Good notes help you locate specific facts when answering detail questions

sections.title: Inference Questions in Listening
sections.body:
Listening inference questions ask you to draw conclusions from what you heard. They use phrases like: "What does the professor imply about...?" or "What can be inferred from the conversation?" The answer is not directly stated but is logically supported by the information provided.

These questions are more challenging than detail questions because you must connect multiple pieces of information. For example, if a professor says that a species thrived when temperatures rose and then mentions that temperatures are currently dropping, you can infer that the species may face challenges.

sections.title: Attitude and Function Questions
sections.body:
Attitude questions ask about a speaker's feelings, opinions, or level of certainty. Function questions ask why a speaker says something specific. Both types may replay a short clip from the passage and ask: "What is the professor's attitude toward...?" or "Why does the student say this?"

Pay attention to tone of voice, word choice, and emphasis. A professor who says "Well, that's one way to look at it" with a skeptical tone is expressing doubt. Hesitation words like "um" or "well" before a response may indicate uncertainty or reluctance to disagree directly.

sections.title: Strategies for These Question Types
sections.body:
For inference questions, focus on cause-and-effect relationships and logical consequences during the lecture. Note when the speaker makes a comparison or presents contrasting information, as inferences often come from these relationships.

For attitude questions, train yourself to listen not just to words but to how they are said. Practice with podcasts or lectures and try to identify the speaker's feelings about the topic. Note any moments of enthusiasm, surprise, concern, or skepticism in your notes with simple markers like (+) for positive and (-) for negative.

key_points.detail: Connect multiple pieces of information to draw a supported conclusion
Listen for tone, enthusiasm, skepticism, and certainty levels
Consider the purpose behind a specific statement in context

key_points.text: Listen to how, not just what
key_points.detail: Tone of voice and emphasis reveal meaning beyond the words themselves

sections.title: Practicing for the Listening Section
sections.body:
Effective Listening practice requires consistent exposure to academic English audio. Use official ETS TOEFL practice tests as your primary resource, supplemented by academic podcasts, university lectures on platforms like Coursera or edX, and TED Talks on academic subjects. The goal is to become comfortable with the pace, vocabulary, and structure of academic spoken English.

Practice under timed conditions to simulate test pressure. Complete an entire Listening section (36 minutes) without pausing. After each practice session, review your answers and notes to identify patterns in the types of questions you miss.

sections.title: Improving Your Listening Skills
sections.body:
Active listening is a skill that improves with deliberate practice. Start by listening to short academic clips (2-3 minutes) and summarizing the main points from memory. Gradually increase the length and complexity of the material. Practice listening without subtitles or transcripts first, then use them to check your comprehension.

Focus on understanding connected speech, where words blend together in natural spoken English. Practice recognizing reduced forms like "gonna" (going to), "wanna" (want to), and "kinda" (kind of), which are common in TOEFL conversations though less frequent in lectures.

sections.title: Common Pitfalls and How to Avoid Them
sections.body:
One major pitfall is losing focus during a long lecture. If you miss a few sentences, do not dwell on them. Keep listening and taking notes on what comes next. You can often piece together missed information from context later.

Another pitfall is spending too long on one question. In the Listening section, you cannot go back to previous questions, so make your best choice and move forward. If you are unsure, use process of elimination and make an educated guess. Never leave a question blank.

key_points.detail: Supplement with academic podcasts, Coursera lectures, and TED Talks
Complete full sections under timed conditions to build stamina

key_points.text: Do not dwell on missed content
key_points.detail: Keep listening forward; you can often recover from context
Answer each question before moving on; never leave questions blank

sections.title: What Is Independent Speaking?
sections.body:
Task 1 is the only independent speaking task on the TOEFL iBT. You are given a prompt asking for your personal opinion, preference, or choice on a familiar topic. You have 15 seconds to prepare and 45 seconds to speak. Topics are general and do not require specialized knowledge, such as "Do you prefer studying alone or in a group?" or "What is the most important quality of a good teacher?"

This task tests your ability to organize your thoughts quickly, deliver a clear response, and support your opinion with reasons and examples. Raters evaluate your delivery (fluency, pronunciation, pacing), language use (grammar, vocabulary), and topic development (coherence, detail).

sections.title: Response Structure
sections.body:
A strong Task 1 response follows a simple structure: state your opinion in one sentence, give your first reason with a brief example or detail, then give your second reason with support. Aim for 2 clear reasons rather than 3 underdeveloped ones. This structure fits naturally within the 45-second time limit.

For example: "I prefer studying in a group for two reasons. First, group study helps me understand difficult concepts because my classmates can explain things from different perspectives. Second, studying with others keeps me motivated and accountable, since I am less likely to get distracted when others are working alongside me."

sections.title: Preparation Tips
sections.body:
Use your 15 seconds of preparation time to jot down 2 key words for your reasons on scratch paper. Do not write full sentences; just enough to guide your response. Practice the 15-second prep until it becomes a habit. Start speaking confidently even if you are still forming your ideas.

Avoid long pauses and filler words like "um" and "uh." If you lose your train of thought, transition to your next point with a phrase like "Another reason is..." rather than stopping. Continuous, natural speech scores better than perfect grammar with long pauses.

key_points.detail: State your opinion, then support with 2 clear reasons and examples
No specialized knowledge needed; topics are about daily life and preferences
Two well-developed reasons are better than three rushed ones
Continuous speech with minor errors scores better than perfect speech with pauses

sections.title: Task 2 Format
sections.body:
Task 2 is an integrated speaking task. First, you read a short passage (about 45-50 seconds) about a campus-related announcement or proposal, such as a change in university policy, a new facility, or a schedule modification. Then you listen to a conversation (about 60-90 seconds) where two students discuss the announcement. One student typically expresses a strong opinion (for or against).

You then have 30 seconds to prepare and 60 seconds to speak. Your task is to summarize the announcement and explain the student's opinion along with the reasons they give. You should not give your own opinion.

sections.title: Response Strategy
sections.body:
Structure your response in three parts. First, briefly summarize the announcement or proposal (1-2 sentences). Second, state the student's opinion (agrees or disagrees). Third, explain the student's two reasons with supporting details from the conversation.

Focus most of your time on the reasons, as this is where you earn the most points. Use reporting language like "The student disagrees because..." or "She argues that..." rather than stating opinions as your own. Paraphrase rather than trying to quote the conversation exactly.

sections.title: Note-Taking for Task 2
sections.body:
While reading the passage, note the main proposal and its key details. While listening to the conversation, identify which student has the strong opinion and write down their two main reasons with any examples they provide. Use a simple two-column format: one side for the reading, one side for the listening.

During your 30-second prep time, quickly organize your notes into the three-part structure: announcement, opinion, reasons. Number your reasons so you can transition smoothly between them during your response.

key_points.detail: Read a campus announcement, listen to a student's reaction, then summarize both
More time than Task 1; use the extra time for detailed reasons
Summarize the student's opinion and reasons; do not add your own view
Briefly summarize the announcement, then spend most time on the student's arguments

sections.title: Task 3 Format
sections.body:
Task 3 is an integrated task that combines academic reading and listening. First, you read a short passage (about 45-50 seconds) that defines an academic concept, theory, or principle from a subject like biology, psychology, business, or art. Then you listen to a lecture (about 60-90 seconds) where a professor illustrates the concept with one or two specific examples.

You have 30 seconds to prepare and 60 seconds to respond. Your task is to explain the concept from the reading and show how the professor's examples illustrate it. This task tests your ability to synthesize information from two sources.

sections.title: Response Structure
sections.body:
Begin with a brief definition of the concept from the reading (1-2 sentences). Then explain how the professor's examples demonstrate the concept. If there are two examples, give roughly equal time to each. Always connect the examples back to the concept explicitly.

For instance: "The reading defines mimicry as when one species evolves to resemble another for protection. The professor illustrates this with two examples. First, he describes the viceroy butterfly, which looks similar to the toxic monarch butterfly. Predators avoid the viceroy because they associate its appearance with the bad taste of the monarch. Second, he mentions..."

sections.title: Connecting Reading and Listening
sections.body:
The most important skill for Task 3 is showing the relationship between the general concept (reading) and the specific examples (lecture). Use connecting phrases like "The professor illustrates this by..." or "This is an example of the concept because..." or "As described in the reading, this demonstrates..."

Do not spend too much time on the reading summary. The lecture examples are where you demonstrate comprehension. Aim for about 10-15 seconds on the concept definition and 45-50 seconds on the examples.

key_points.detail: Reading provides the theory; lecture provides real-world examples
Explicitly connect the professor's examples to the concept from the reading
Spend 10-15 seconds on the concept, then 45-50 seconds on examples
Phrases like 'This illustrates...' and 'As the reading explains...' show synthesis

sections.title: Task 4 Format
sections.body:
Task 4 is the most challenging speaking task. There is no reading passage; you only listen to a lecture (about 90-120 seconds) where a professor discusses an academic topic, typically explaining a concept and providing examples or describing a process with steps. You then have 20 seconds to prepare and 60 seconds to summarize the key points of the lecture.

This task requires strong listening and note-taking skills because you must capture and organize all the information from the lecture alone. Topics come from various academic disciplines and may involve classifications, processes, cause-effect relationships, or comparisons.

sections.title: Note-Taking Strategy for Task 4
sections.body:
Since there is no reading to anchor your understanding, your notes are critical. Listen for the professor's main point or thesis first. Then identify the organizational structure: Is the professor giving examples of a concept? Describing steps in a process? Comparing two approaches? Explaining causes and effects?

Write down the main topic, then use numbered points for each example, step, or sub-topic. Include 1-2 key details for each point. If the professor gives two examples, note what makes each one distinct and how they relate to the main concept.

sections.title: Delivering Your Response
sections.body:
Start with a clear statement of the lecture's main topic. Then present the key points in the same order the professor used. For each point, state the main idea and provide one or two supporting details. Use transitions like "First," "Second," "Additionally," and "The professor also explains that..."

Do not try to include every detail from the lecture. Select the most important information and present it clearly. A well-organized response covering the main points will score higher than a disorganized attempt to include everything.

key_points.detail: All information comes from a 90-120 second academic lecture
Less prep time than Tasks 2-3; strong notes are essential
Determine if the lecture uses examples, steps, comparisons, or cause-effect
Cover main ideas clearly rather than trying to include every detail

sections.title: Managing Your Speaking Time
sections.body:
Each speaking task has a strict time limit that cannot be extended. For Task 1 (45 seconds), aim to finish your second reason about 5 seconds before time runs out. For Tasks 2-4 (60 seconds), plan your response so that each major point gets roughly equal time. Running out of time mid-sentence is common but not ideal.

Practice with a timer constantly. Record yourself and check whether you finish your responses within the time limit. If you consistently run out of time, simplify your responses by reducing details rather than speaking faster. Clear, paced speech at a natural speed scores better than rushed delivery.

sections.title: Improving Fluency and Pronunciation
sections.body:
Fluency means speaking smoothly without excessive pauses, repetitions, or self-corrections. To improve fluency, practice speaking on various topics for 45-60 seconds without stopping. Record yourself and listen for hesitations. Common fluency killers include searching for the "perfect" word and trying to use overly complex grammar.

For pronunciation, focus on clarity rather than accent elimination. Ensure your word stress, sentence stress, and intonation patterns are natural. Practice problem sounds specific to your native language. For Indonesian speakers, pay attention to final consonant clusters, the th-sounds, and the distinction between long and short vowels.

sections.title: Scoring Rubric Awareness
sections.body:
TOEFL Speaking is scored on a 0-4 scale for each task, then converted to 0-30. A score of 4 (highest) requires generally clear and fluid speech, effective use of grammar and vocabulary, and well-developed responses with coherent ideas. A score of 3 means the response is mostly clear with some fluency issues and adequate development.

Raters understand that 45-60 seconds is not much time. They do not expect perfection. Minor grammatical errors, slight hesitations, and small pronunciation issues will not significantly hurt your score if your overall message is clear and well-organized. Focus on communication effectiveness over perfection.

key_points.detail: Record yourself and ensure you finish within time limits consistently
Clear, well-paced speech scores better than rushed, hard-to-follow delivery
Minor errors are acceptable; long pauses and repetitions hurt scores more
Scored 0-4 on delivery, language use, and topic development

sections.title: How to Practice Speaking Effectively
sections.body:
The best way to improve TOEFL Speaking is through daily timed practice. Use official ETS practice prompts or create your own based on common topics (education, technology, daily life, work). Set a timer for 15 seconds of prep and 45 seconds of speaking for Task 1 practice, and 30 seconds prep with 60 seconds speaking for integrated task practice.

Record every practice response and listen to it critically. Evaluate your own fluency, pronunciation, grammar, vocabulary, and whether you fully addressed the prompt. Compare your responses to high-scoring sample responses available from ETS to understand what a 4-level response sounds like.

sections.title: Building a Practice Routine
sections.body:
Dedicate 20-30 minutes daily to speaking practice. Start with 5 minutes of warm-up: read a short passage aloud to get comfortable speaking English. Then complete 3-4 timed practice responses. Finish by listening to your recordings and noting one specific area to improve in your next session.

Vary your practice topics and task types. Do not just practice Task 1; integrated tasks (2, 3, and 4) require different skills. Practice note-taking while listening, then speaking from your notes. This multi-skill practice mirrors the actual test experience.

sections.title: Common Speaking Mistakes
sections.body:
Avoid these frequent mistakes: going off-topic or not answering the specific question asked, giving a list of reasons without developing any of them, using memorized templates that sound unnatural, speaking too quietly or too close to the microphone, and failing to use transition words between ideas.

Also avoid the trap of speaking in your native language patterns. For example, do not translate directly from Indonesian. Instead, think in simple English structures and build from there. It is better to use simple, correct sentences than complex, incorrect ones.

key_points.detail: 20-30 minutes per day with a timer and recording device
Listen to your responses critically and identify specific areas to improve
Each task requires different skills; do not only practice Task 1
Use simple, correct English structures rather than translating from your native language

sections.title: Task Format
sections.body:
The Integrated Writing Task is the first writing task on the TOEFL iBT. You read a passage (about 250-300 words) on an academic topic for 3 minutes. Then you listen to a lecture (about 2 minutes) that challenges or contradicts the points made in the reading. The reading passage reappears on screen while you write your response in 20 minutes.

Your task is to summarize the points made in the lecture and explain how they relate to (usually challenge or cast doubt on) the points in the reading passage. You should write 150-225 words. This task tests your ability to synthesize information from reading and listening sources.

sections.title: Response Structure
sections.body:
Use a clear four-paragraph structure. The introduction states that the lecture challenges the reading's claims (1-2 sentences). Then write three body paragraphs, each addressing one point where the lecture contradicts the reading. For each body paragraph, briefly state the reading's claim, then explain how the lecture counters it.

Use contrast language throughout: "While the reading states that..., the professor argues that..." or "The reading claims X; however, the lecturer provides evidence that..." This structure clearly demonstrates your ability to connect the two sources.

sections.title: Note-Taking During the Lecture
sections.body:
While reading the passage, identify and note the three main points or arguments. When the lecture begins, listen for how the professor addresses each point. The lecture almost always follows the same order as the reading. Write down the professor's counterarguments and any specific evidence or examples given.

Organize your notes in a two-column format: reading points on the left, lecture counterpoints on the right. This makes it easy to write your response by working through each row of your notes.

key_points.detail: 3 min reading + 2 min lecture + 20 min writing; reading stays on screen
The lecture typically contradicts or casts doubt on the reading's claims
Intro + 3 body paragraphs, each pairing a reading point with its counter
Focus on accuracy and synthesis rather than length

sections.title: Writing for an Academic Discussion
sections.body:
The current TOEFL iBT features a task called "Writing for an Academic Discussion" (replacing the traditional independent essay). You read a professor's question and two student responses in an online discussion format. You then have 10 minutes to write your own contribution to the discussion, adding a new idea, perspective, or example that builds on what has already been said.

Your response should be at least 100 words. You should take a clear position, provide specific reasons or examples, and connect your ideas to the discussion. This task tests your ability to contribute meaningfully to an academic conversation in writing.

sections.title: Response Strategy
sections.body:
Read the professor's question carefully to understand exactly what is being discussed. Then read both student responses to see what positions and arguments have already been made. Your contribution should add something new: a different perspective, an additional reason, a counterargument, or a specific example that has not been mentioned.

Start by stating your position clearly, then develop it with 1-2 specific reasons or examples. You may agree with one student and expand on their point, disagree and explain why, or take a completely new angle. Reference the other students' ideas using phrases like "While I agree with Sarah's point about..., I would add that..."

sections.title: Time Management in 10 Minutes
sections.body:
With only 10 minutes, efficiency is critical. Spend 2 minutes reading the prompt and planning your response. Spend 7 minutes writing. Spend 1 minute proofreading for grammar and spelling errors. Do not agonize over choosing a position; pick one quickly and commit to it.

Write clearly and concisely. You do not need a formal essay structure with an introduction, body, and conclusion. A focused, well-developed paragraph of 100-150 words that directly addresses the discussion is sufficient for a high score.

key_points.detail: Read a professor's question and two student posts, then contribute your own idea
Do not repeat what students said; bring a new perspective, reason, or example
A focused paragraph of 100-150 words with clear reasoning is sufficient
2 minutes reading/planning, 7 minutes writing, 1 minute proofreading

sections.title: Note-Taking for Integrated Writing
sections.body:
Effective notes are the foundation of a strong integrated writing response. While reading the passage, identify the thesis and three main supporting points. Write each point as a brief phrase. When the lecture begins, listen for how the professor addresses each point and note the counterarguments alongside your reading notes.

Use a T-chart format with the reading on the left and lecture on the right. This visual organization makes it easy to write each body paragraph by simply working through your chart. Include specific details like names, dates, or statistics from the lecture, as these strengthen your response.

sections.title: Capturing Key Details from the Lecture
sections.body:
The lecture is the more challenging source because you hear it only once. Focus on capturing the professor's main counterarguments and any specific evidence. Listen for signal phrases like "Actually, research shows..." or "But what the reading fails to mention is..." These indicate key points to note.

Do not try to write complete sentences during the lecture. Use keywords, abbreviations, and arrows to connect ideas. After the lecture ends and the writing prompt appears, spend 30-60 seconds organizing your notes before you start typing.

sections.title: Organizing Notes for the Academic Discussion
sections.body:
For the Academic Discussion task, note-taking is simpler but still important. As you read the professor's question and student responses, jot down the key positions taken and any arguments already made. This helps you quickly identify what has been covered so you can add something new.

Note any points you agree or disagree with and think of a specific example from your experience or knowledge. Your notes for this task should take only about 60 seconds, leaving you the maximum time for writing and proofreading.

key_points.detail: Reading points on the left, lecture counterpoints on the right
Use abbreviations and arrows during the lecture to keep up
Names, statistics, and examples from the lecture strengthen your response
60 seconds of notes for the Academic Discussion task is sufficient

sections.title: Organizing Your Integrated Response
sections.body:
A well-organized integrated writing response follows a predictable pattern that raters can easily follow. Start with an introductory sentence that frames the relationship between the reading and lecture. Then present three body paragraphs, each addressing one point of contrast between the two sources.

Within each body paragraph, follow this pattern: state the reading's claim (1 sentence), present the lecture's counterargument (2-3 sentences), and optionally note the specific evidence the professor provides. This consistent structure helps you write quickly and ensures you cover all points.

sections.title: Essential Transition Words and Phrases
sections.body:
Transitions connect your ideas and show relationships between them. For contrast (most common in integrated writing): however, on the other hand, in contrast, nevertheless, while, whereas, although. For addition: furthermore, moreover, additionally, in addition. For examples: for instance, for example, specifically, in particular.

For cause and effect: as a result, consequently, therefore, because of this. For sequence: first, second, finally, to begin with. Using varied transitions throughout your response demonstrates language proficiency and improves coherence.

sections.title: Coherence and Flow
sections.body:
Coherence means your ideas flow logically from one to the next. Beyond using transition words, achieve coherence by repeating key terms from the prompt, using pronouns to refer back to previously mentioned ideas, and maintaining a consistent focus on the topic throughout your response.

Avoid jumping between ideas without clear connections. Each sentence should relate to the one before it and lead to the one after it. Read your response once before submitting to check that the logical flow is clear and that you have not accidentally contradicted yourself.

key_points.detail: Reading claim + lecture counter + evidence in each body paragraph
Contrast, addition, example, and sequence words show language proficiency
Repeat key terms and use pronouns to connect sentences smoothly
Check that ideas flow logically and you have not contradicted yourself

sections.title: Practicing Integrated Writing
sections.body:
Use official ETS TOEFL practice materials to simulate the integrated writing task. Read the passage for 3 minutes, listen to the lecture, then write your response in 20 minutes. After finishing, compare your response to the sample responses provided by ETS at different score levels (good, fair, limited).

Pay attention to whether you accurately captured the lecture's main points and how well you connected them to the reading. Common issues include misrepresenting the lecture's arguments, focusing too much on the reading while neglecting the lecture, and failing to show the relationship between the two sources.

sections.title: Practicing the Academic Discussion
sections.body:
For the Academic Discussion task, practice writing focused responses in exactly 10 minutes. Find or create prompts that present a professor's question with two student viewpoints. Set a timer and practice the 2-7-1 time split: 2 minutes reading and planning, 7 minutes writing, 1 minute reviewing.

After each practice session, review your response for: clear position statement, specific supporting reasons or examples, connection to the existing discussion, grammatical accuracy, and appropriate vocabulary. Aim to write naturally and conversationally while maintaining academic standards.

sections.title: Improving Your Writing Score
sections.body:
To move from a score of 3 to 4 or 5, focus on these areas. For the integrated task: ensure you accurately represent both sources and clearly show how the lecture challenges the reading. For the academic discussion: make sure your contribution is substantial and adds genuine value to the conversation.

Common grammar issues that lower scores include subject-verb agreement errors, incorrect verb tenses, run-on sentences, and article misuse. Proofread specifically for these patterns. Expanding your academic vocabulary also helps, as varied and precise word choice is a scoring criterion.

sections.title: Why Word Parts Matter
sections.body:
Understanding word roots, prefixes, and suffixes is one of the most efficient strategies for expanding your TOEFL vocabulary. Instead of memorizing thousands of individual words, learning common word parts allows you to decode unfamiliar words by breaking them into meaningful components. This skill is especially valuable for vocabulary-in-context questions in the Reading section.

For example, knowing that "bene-" means "good" helps you understand words like beneficial, benevolent, and benediction even if you have never seen them before. Similarly, knowing that "-ology" means "study of" connects biology, psychology, and geology.

sections.title: Common Prefixes
sections.body:
Master these high-frequency prefixes for the TOEFL: "un-/in-/im-/dis-" (not): unusual, incomplete, impossible, disagree. "re-" (again): reconsider, restructure. "pre-" (before): prerequisite, predict. "post-" (after): postgraduate, postpone. "mis-" (wrongly): misinterpret, misleading. "over-" (too much): overestimate, overlook. "under-" (too little): underestimate, undermine.

Also learn "inter-" (between): interact, interdisciplinary. "trans-" (across): transform, transport. "sub-" (under/below): subsequent, subordinate. "co-/com-/con-" (together): collaborate, community, contribute. These prefixes appear constantly in academic texts.

sections.title: Common Roots and Suffixes
sections.body:
Key Latin and Greek roots include: "dict" (say): predict, contradict. "duct/duc" (lead): produce, conduct. "struct" (build): construct, infrastructure. "spec/spect" (look): perspective, inspect. "port" (carry): transport, import. "vert/vers" (turn): convert, reverse.

Important suffixes indicate word type: "-tion/-sion" (noun): investigation, conclusion. "-ment" (noun): development, environment. "-ous/-ive/-al" (adjective): various, effective, fundamental. "-ly" (adverb): significantly, approximately. "-ize" (verb): analyze, characterize. Recognizing these helps you identify a word's part of speech even when its meaning is unclear.

sections.title: Biology and Life Sciences
sections.body:
Biology-related passages appear frequently on the TOEFL. Essential vocabulary includes: organism, species, habitat, ecosystem, biodiversity, evolution, adaptation, natural selection, predator, prey, symbiosis, photosynthesis, reproduction, genetics, and extinction. Understanding these terms helps you follow passages about animal behavior, ecological systems, and evolutionary processes.

Related academic verbs include: evolve, adapt, migrate, inhabit, reproduce, thrive, decline, and fluctuate. These words often appear in vocabulary-in-context questions where you must determine their specific meaning in a science passage.

sections.title: Earth and Physical Sciences
sections.body:
Geology and physical science topics are also common. Key terms include: erosion, sediment, fossil, tectonic plates, volcanic, glacier, atmosphere, precipitation, condensation, mineral, compound, element, molecule, and particle. For astronomy: orbit, galaxy, solar system, celestial, and gravitational.

Process-related vocabulary is especially important: formation, decomposition, crystallization, evaporation, and accumulation. TOEFL passages often describe scientific processes step by step, so understanding these terms helps you follow the sequence of events described in the text.

sections.title: Strategies for Science Vocabulary
sections.body:
When encountering unfamiliar science terms on the TOEFL, remember that the passage usually provides enough context to understand them. Professors and academic writers typically define technical terms when they first introduce them, using phrases like "known as," "which is," or "in other words."

Build your science vocabulary by reading popular science articles regularly. Sources like Scientific American, Nature News, and BBC Science are excellent because they explain complex concepts in accessible language, similar to TOEFL passage style.

key_points.detail: Learn terms for ecology, evolution, and animal behavior
Words like formation, erosion, and decomposition describe scientific sequences
Passages usually define specialized vocabulary when introducing it
Scientific American and BBC Science mirror TOEFL passage difficulty

sections.title: Psychology and Sociology
sections.body:
Social science passages frequently appear on the TOEFL, particularly from psychology and sociology. Key psychology terms include: behavior, cognition, perception, stimulus, response, conditioning, reinforcement, motivation, development, and consciousness. For sociology: society, culture, norms, institutions, stratification, demographics, urbanization, and socialization.

Research-related vocabulary is essential: hypothesis, variable, correlation, experiment, observation, survey, sample, bias, and findings. TOEFL passages often describe research studies, so understanding the scientific method vocabulary helps you follow the logic of the passage.

sections.title: History and Anthropology
sections.body:
Historical and anthropological passages cover topics like civilizations, cultural development, and historical events. Important terms include: civilization, agriculture, settlement, migration, colonization, revolution, reform, dynasty, artifact, excavation, and indigenous. Understanding era-related vocabulary like medieval, ancient, contemporary, and prehistoric helps you place events in context.

Transition and change vocabulary is crucial for history passages: emergence, decline, transformation, transition, era, epoch, and milestone. These words describe how societies, cultures, and technologies developed over time.

sections.title: Building Social Science Vocabulary
sections.body:
Social science vocabulary often overlaps with everyday English but carries more specific academic meanings. For example, "culture" in everyday English might mean arts and entertainment, but in social science it refers to the shared beliefs, values, and practices of a group. Similarly, "institution" might mean a building, but in sociology it refers to established social structures like family, education, or government.

Practice identifying these academic-specific meanings by reading university-level textbook introductions in psychology, sociology, and history. Pay attention to how authors define and use key terms differently from their everyday usage.

key_points.detail: Hypothesis, variable, correlation, bias, and findings appear in many passages
Learn words describing emergence, decline, transformation, and transitions

sections.title: Art and Architecture
sections.body:
TOEFL passages about art and architecture use specialized vocabulary you should recognize. Key terms include: aesthetic, composition, perspective, symmetry, abstract, figurative, medium (plural: media), technique, genre, style, movement, patronage, commission, and masterpiece. For architecture: structure, facade, dome, column, foundation, blueprint, and renovation.

Art history passages often discuss artistic movements (Renaissance, Impressionism, Modernism) and the social or cultural factors that influenced them. Understanding how art connects to historical context is a common theme in TOEFL reading passages.

sections.title: Literature and Philosophy
sections.body:
Literature-related vocabulary includes: narrative, protagonist, allegory, metaphor, symbolism, theme, genre, prose, verse, criticism, and interpretation. For philosophy: concept, theory, argument, premise, logic, ethics, moral, rational, empirical, and abstract.

These fields share evaluative vocabulary that appears across many TOEFL topics: significant, innovative, influential, controversial, fundamental, profound, conventional, and radical. These adjectives often appear in vocabulary-in-context questions where you must determine the precise shade of meaning.

sections.title: Engaging with Arts and Humanities Texts
sections.body:
Many test-takers find arts and humanities passages challenging because the topics seem subjective compared to science. The key is to focus on the author's argument structure: What claim is being made? What evidence supports it? How does the author evaluate the significance of the topic?

Practice reading art reviews, museum descriptions, and cultural essays. Pay attention to how writers describe and evaluate creative works. Notice the difference between objective description ("The painting depicts a rural landscape") and subjective interpretation ("The artist conveys a sense of isolation through muted colors").

key_points.detail: Learn aesthetic, composition, perspective, medium, genre, and movement
Words like significant, innovative, and controversial appear in many passages
Even in arts passages, identify the author's claim, evidence, and evaluation
Distinguish between describing what something is and interpreting what it means

sections.title: Argument and Analysis Words
sections.body:
Academic discourse vocabulary refers to the words used to build, discuss, and evaluate arguments across all disciplines. These words appear in every TOEFL passage regardless of topic. Key terms include: assert, claim, contend, argue, maintain, suggest, propose, refute, challenge, dispute, support, demonstrate, and illustrate.

Understanding the strength of these verbs matters. "Suggest" implies a tentative idea, while "assert" implies confidence. "Demonstrate" implies proof, while "indicate" implies evidence that points in a direction. These distinctions are often tested in inference and rhetorical purpose questions.

sections.title: Cause, Effect, and Comparison
sections.body:
Words expressing causation include: cause, result in, lead to, contribute to, stem from, give rise to, trigger, and attribute to. Words expressing effect: consequence, outcome, impact, implication, and repercussion. These appear in passages describing scientific discoveries, historical events, and social phenomena.

Comparison and contrast vocabulary is equally important: similar, analogous, comparable, equivalent, distinct, differ, whereas, in contrast, conversely, and on the other hand. TOEFL passages frequently compare two theories, approaches, species, or historical periods.

sections.title: Degree and Certainty Words
sections.body:
Academic writing uses hedging and boosting language to indicate levels of certainty. Hedging words (less certain): perhaps, possibly, might, may, tend to, appear to, somewhat, and relatively. Boosting words (more certain): clearly, definitely, certainly, undoubtedly, significantly, and fundamentally.

Recognizing these words helps you answer inference and attitude questions accurately. If a passage says "This may have contributed to the decline," you cannot infer that it definitely caused the decline. Pay close attention to these qualifying words when evaluating answer choices.

sections.title: University System Vocabulary
sections.body:
TOEFL Listening conversations often take place in university settings, so knowing campus vocabulary is essential. Academic terms include: semester, credit, prerequisite, syllabus, enrollment, registration, major, minor, elective, thesis, dissertation, GPA, transcript, and dean's list. Administrative terms include: registrar, bursar, financial aid, scholarship, tuition, and deadline.

Understanding the American university system helps you follow conversations about course selection, graduation requirements, and academic advising. For example, knowing that a "prerequisite" is a required course you must complete before taking another course helps you understand scheduling discussions.

sections.title: Campus Locations and Services
sections.body:
Conversations reference specific campus locations and services: library (reference desk, stacks, reserves, interlibrary loan), dormitory/residence hall, student center, cafeteria, health center, career services, tutoring center, writing lab, and administrative offices. Knowing these terms helps you immediately understand the context of a conversation.

Common campus activities include: office hours, study groups, club meetings, orientation, commencement, and field trips. Understanding these concepts helps you follow conversations where students discuss their schedules, extracurricular activities, or interactions with professors and staff.

sections.title: Informal Campus Language
sections.body:
TOEFL conversations use informal language that differs from academic writing. Learn common phrases: "sign up for" (register), "drop a class" (withdraw), "pull an all-nighter" (study all night), "catch up on" (complete overdue work), "hand in" (submit), "figure out" (understand/solve), "look into" (investigate), and "put off" (postpone).

Also learn polite request and suggestion forms used in campus interactions: "I was wondering if..." (polite request), "Have you thought about..." (suggestion), "You might want to..." (gentle advice), and "I'm afraid that..." (delivering bad news politely). These pragmatic phrases are often tested in function questions.
