sections.title: What Are Collocations?
sections.body:
Collocations are word combinations that frequently occur together in natural English. For example, we say "make a decision" (not "do a decision") and "conduct research" (not "make research"). Using correct collocations improves both your writing and speaking scores because they make your language sound natural and fluent.

Academic collocations are especially important for TOEFL. Common examples include: draw a conclusion, raise a question, pose a challenge, gain insight, play a role, take into account, shed light on, and carry out an experiment. Learning these as fixed phrases is more efficient than memorizing individual words.

sections.title: Word Families
sections.body:
A word family includes all the forms of a word across different parts of speech. For example: analyze (verb), analysis (noun), analytical (adjective), analytically (adverb). Learning word families helps you use the right form in your writing and speaking, and helps you recognize words in reading passages.

High-value word families for TOEFL include: significant/significance/significantly, contribute/contribution/contributor, establish/establishment/established, interpret/interpretation/interpretive, and approach/approachable/unapproachable. Practice converting words between their different forms.

sections.title: Building Collocation Knowledge
sections.body:
To learn collocations effectively, do not study words in isolation. Always note the words that appear around your target vocabulary. When you learn "significant," also learn "significant impact," "significant difference," "significant contribution," and "statistically significant."

Keep a collocation notebook organized by topic. When reading academic texts, underline word combinations that seem to go together naturally. Practice using these collocations in your writing and speaking responses. Over time, they will become automatic parts of your vocabulary.

sections.title: Effective Vocabulary Study Methods
sections.body:
Research shows that active recall and spaced repetition are the most effective methods for long-term vocabulary retention. Use flashcard apps like Anki that schedule reviews based on how well you remember each word. Create cards with the word on one side and its definition, example sentence, and common collocations on the other.

Study vocabulary in context rather than memorizing word lists. When you encounter a new word in a reading passage, write down the full sentence and try to guess the meaning before looking it up. This contextual learning creates stronger memory connections than rote memorization.

sections.title: Vocabulary Strategies for Test Day
sections.body:
On test day, use these strategies for unfamiliar words. First, check for context clues in surrounding sentences. Second, analyze the word parts (prefixes, roots, suffixes). Third, consider the word's function in the sentence (noun, verb, adjective). Fourth, use process of elimination to narrow down answer choices.

For vocabulary-in-context questions, always substitute your answer choice back into the original sentence to verify it works. The correct answer will maintain the meaning and grammatical structure of the original sentence. Be wary of answer choices that are synonyms of the word in general but do not fit the specific context.

sections.title: Weekly Review Plan
sections.body:
Establish a weekly vocabulary review routine. Monday through Friday, learn 10-15 new words daily from academic sources. Each weekend, review all words from the week using flashcards or practice exercises. At the end of each month, test yourself on all words learned that month.

Focus on high-frequency academic words rather than obscure vocabulary. The Academic Word List (AWL) and the TOEFL vocabulary lists published by major test prep companies cover the most commonly tested words. Prioritize words you encounter repeatedly in practice tests, as these are most likely to appear on your actual test.

key_points.detail: Use flashcard apps like Anki for scheduled reviews based on recall difficulty
Study words in full sentences from real passages, not isolated word lists
Context clues, word parts, sentence function, then process of elimination

sections.title: The Four Sentence Types
sections.body:
English has four sentence types based on clause structure. A simple sentence has one independent clause: "The experiment produced unexpected results." A compound sentence joins two independent clauses with a coordinating conjunction (for, and, nor, but, or, yet, so): "The experiment was controversial, but its findings were significant."

A complex sentence combines an independent clause with one or more dependent clauses: "Although the experiment was controversial, its findings changed the field." A compound-complex sentence has at least two independent clauses and one dependent clause: "Although the initial results were promising, the researchers needed more data, and they extended the study by six months."

sections.title: Using Sentence Variety in TOEFL Writing
sections.body:
TOEFL Writing raters look for sentence variety as evidence of language proficiency. A response that uses only simple sentences will score lower than one that mixes simple, compound, and complex sentences. Practice combining short sentences into more sophisticated structures.

However, do not force complexity at the expense of clarity. A clear, grammatically correct simple sentence is better than a confusing complex sentence. Aim for a natural mix: start with a complex or compound sentence for your main point, use simple sentences for emphasis, and use compound sentences to show relationships between ideas.

sections.title: Common Sentence Structure Errors
sections.body:
Avoid these frequent errors in TOEFL Writing and Speaking. Run-on sentences occur when two independent clauses are joined without proper punctuation or a conjunction: "The study was important it changed how scientists think" (incorrect). Fix with a period, semicolon, or conjunction. Sentence fragments lack either a subject or a verb: "Because the results were surprising" (fragment; needs an independent clause).

Comma splices join two independent clauses with only a comma: "The data was clear, the theory needed revision" (incorrect). Fix by adding a conjunction after the comma, replacing the comma with a semicolon, or making two separate sentences.

Mix sentence types naturally in writing for higher language use scores

sections.title: Types of Transitions
sections.body:
Transitions are words and phrases that connect ideas and show relationships between sentences and paragraphs. They fall into several categories based on the relationship they express. Addition: furthermore, moreover, in addition, also, additionally. Contrast: however, nevertheless, on the other hand, in contrast, whereas, although. Cause/Effect: therefore, consequently, as a result, thus, hence.

Example: for instance, for example, specifically, to illustrate. Time: subsequently, meanwhile, previously, eventually, simultaneously. Summary: in conclusion, to summarize, overall, in brief. Mastering these categories helps you choose the right transition for each context.

sections.title: Using Transitions Effectively
sections.body:
Transitions should clarify the logical relationship between ideas, not just fill space. Before choosing a transition, identify the relationship: Are you adding information? Contrasting ideas? Showing a result? Then select a transition that accurately reflects that relationship. Using "however" when you mean "furthermore" confuses the reader and lowers your coherence score.

In TOEFL Writing, place transitions at the beginning of sentences or clauses for clarity. Vary your transitions rather than repeating the same one. For example, instead of using "however" three times, alternate with "nevertheless," "on the other hand," and "in contrast." This variety demonstrates language range.

sections.title: Transitions in Reading Comprehension
sections.body:
Recognizing transitions in reading passages helps you understand the author's argument structure and predict what comes next. When you see "however" or "nevertheless," expect a contrasting idea. When you see "for example" or "specifically," expect an illustration of the previous point. When you see "therefore" or "as a result," expect a conclusion or consequence.

Insert text questions rely heavily on transition recognition. The new sentence often contains a transition that tells you exactly where it belongs. If the sentence starts with "In contrast," it must follow a point that the sentence contradicts. This makes transitions one of your most powerful tools for answering these questions correctly.

grammar_patterns.explanation: Show opposition or unexpected information. 'However' and 'nevertheless' are adverbs that start new sentences. 'Although' and 'whereas' are conjunctions that connect clauses within a sentence.

sections.title: What Is Parallel Structure?
sections.body:
Parallel structure (also called parallelism) means using the same grammatical form for items in a list, comparison, or paired construction. When you list three activities, all three should be in the same form. Correct: "The study involved collecting data, analyzing results, and writing conclusions." Incorrect: "The study involved collecting data, analysis of results, and to write conclusions."

Parallelism applies to words, phrases, and clauses. It makes writing clearer and more professional. In TOEFL Writing, using correct parallel structure demonstrates grammatical control and improves your language use score.

sections.title: Parallelism with Conjunctions and Comparisons
sections.body:
Coordinating conjunctions (and, but, or) require parallel elements on both sides. "She enjoys reading and writing" is correct (two gerunds). "She enjoys reading and to write" is incorrect (gerund + infinitive). The same rule applies to correlative conjunctions: both...and, either...or, neither...nor, not only...but also.

Comparisons also require parallelism. "Running is better exercise than swimming" is correct (gerund compared to gerund). "Running is better exercise than to swim" is incorrect. With "rather than" and "more than," ensure both sides match in form.

sections.title: Applying Parallelism in TOEFL Responses
sections.body:
In your TOEFL Writing and Speaking, use parallel structure when listing reasons, describing processes, or making comparisons. This not only avoids grammar errors but also makes your ideas easier to follow. Raters notice when lists and comparisons are grammatically consistent.

Before submitting your writing, check any sentence with a list or comparison. Ensure all items match in form. A quick check: can you strip the sentence down to just the list items and confirm they are all nouns, all verbs, or all adjective phrases? If they mix forms, revise for parallelism.

sections.title: Adjective and Adverb Usage
sections.body:
Adjectives modify nouns ("a significant discovery"), while adverbs modify verbs, adjectives, or other adverbs ("significantly improved," "extremely important"). Confusing these is a common error. Use adjectives after linking verbs like "be," "seem," "appear," and "become": "The results seem conclusive" (not "conclusively").

In TOEFL Writing, precise modifier use demonstrates language control. Instead of "very good results," use "excellent results" or "remarkably positive results." Specific modifiers like "approximately," "primarily," "substantially," and "predominantly" show academic vocabulary range and earn higher language use scores.

sections.title: Comparative and Superlative Forms
sections.body:
Comparatives compare two items: add "-er" to short adjectives (larger, faster) or use "more" with longer adjectives (more significant, more effective). Superlatives compare three or more items: add "-est" (largest, fastest) or use "most" (most significant, most effective). Never use both forms together: "more larger" is always incorrect.

Irregular forms to memorize: good/better/best, bad/worse/worst, far/farther(further)/farthest(furthest), little/less/least, much-many/more/most. In academic writing, you will frequently use phrases like "The most compelling evidence," "A more effective approach," and "Less significant than previously thought."

sections.title: Dangling and Misplaced Modifiers
sections.body:
A dangling modifier occurs when the word it is supposed to modify is missing from the sentence. "Walking through the forest, the trees were enormous" is incorrect because "walking" has no clear subject; trees do not walk. Correct: "Walking through the forest, we noticed the enormous trees."

A misplaced modifier is positioned too far from the word it modifies, creating confusion. "The professor discussed the experiment that failed briefly" is ambiguous. Did the experiment fail briefly, or did the professor discuss it briefly? Correct: "The professor briefly discussed the experiment that failed." Place modifiers as close as possible to the words they describe.

grammar_patterns.tip: Use 'than' after comparatives and 'as...as' for equal comparisons. Never mix the two forms.

grammar_patterns.title: Modifier Placement
grammar_patterns.explanation: Modifying phrases at the beginning of a sentence must describe the subject that immediately follows. A dangling modifier occurs when the subject does not match the modifier.
grammar_patterns.formula: Modifier phrase + , + Subject (that the modifier describes) + Verb

examples.en: Conducted over five years, the study revealed significant trends.
examples.id: Dilakukan selama lima tahun, studi tersebut mengungkapkan tren signifikan.

examples.en: Conducted over five years, the trends were significant.
examples.id: Dilakukan selama lima tahun, trennya signifikan. (dangling modifier)

grammar_patterns.tip: After a modifying phrase, ask: Does the subject actually perform or receive the action in the modifier?

sections.title: Basic Agreement Rules
sections.body:
Subject-verb agreement means the verb form must match the subject in number. Singular subjects take singular verbs: "The study shows promising results." Plural subjects take plural verbs: "The studies show promising results." This seems simple, but errors are common when the subject is separated from the verb by prepositional phrases or other modifiers.

For example: "The results of the experiment show..." (not "shows" -- the subject is "results," not "experiment"). "The professor, along with her students, is..." (not "are" -- the subject is "professor"; "along with" does not make it plural). Always identify the true subject before choosing the verb form.

sections.title: Tricky Agreement Cases
sections.body:
Several situations frequently cause agreement errors. Indefinite pronouns like "everyone," "each," "nobody," and "either" are singular: "Each of the participants was given a questionnaire." Collective nouns like "team," "group," and "committee" are usually singular in American English: "The team is conducting research."

With "there is/there are" constructions, the verb agrees with the subject that follows: "There are several reasons for this" (reasons is plural). With "neither...nor" and "either...or," the verb agrees with the nearest subject: "Neither the students nor the professor was available" (professor is singular).

sections.title: Agreement in Academic Writing
sections.body:
In TOEFL Writing, subject-verb agreement errors are noticeable and can lower your score. Pay special attention to long subjects with multiple modifiers, as it is easy to lose track of the main noun. When proofreading, find each verb and trace it back to its subject to verify agreement.

Also watch for agreement with uncountable nouns. Words like "information," "research," "evidence," "knowledge," and "equipment" are always singular: "The evidence suggests..." (not "suggest"). "The research indicates..." (not "indicate"). These academic nouns are commonly used on the TOEFL.

key_points.detail: Ignore prepositional phrases between subject and verb
Everyone, each, nobody, and either take singular verbs
Information, research, evidence, and equipment take singular verbs
Find each verb and identify its subject to verify agreement

grammar_patterns.title: Agreement with Intervening Phrases
grammar_patterns.explanation: Prepositional phrases, relative clauses, and other modifiers between the subject and verb do not change the subject's number. The verb must agree with the main subject, not the nearest noun.
grammar_patterns.formula: Subject + [prepositional phrase / modifier] + Verb (agrees with Subject)

examples.en: The analysis of the collected samples indicates a clear pattern.
examples.id: Analisis dari sampel yang dikumpulkan menunjukkan pola yang jelas.

examples.en: The analysis of the collected samples indicate a clear pattern.
examples.id: Analisis dari sampel yang dikumpulkan menunjukkan pola yang jelas. (salah: 'indicate' harusnya 'indicates')

grammar_patterns.tip: Cross out the words between the subject and verb to see the true agreement clearly.

grammar_patterns.title: There Is / There Are
grammar_patterns.explanation: In sentences beginning with 'there,' the verb agrees with the subject that follows it, not with 'there' itself.
grammar_patterns.formula: There + is/are + Subject (determines verb form)

examples.en: There are several factors that contribute to this phenomenon.
examples.id: Ada beberapa faktor yang berkontribusi pada fenomena ini.

examples.en: There is several factors that contribute to this phenomenon.
examples.id: Ada beberapa faktor yang berkontribusi pada fenomena ini. (salah: 'is' harusnya 'are')

grammar_patterns.tip: Read the sentence without 'there' to find the real subject and check agreement.

sections.title: Applying Grammar to TOEFL Tasks
sections.body:
Grammar knowledge directly impacts your TOEFL scores in multiple sections. In Writing, grammatical accuracy and variety are explicit scoring criteria. In Speaking, raters evaluate your grammar as part of the language use component. Even in Reading, understanding sentence structure helps you parse complex academic sentences and answer questions more accurately.

The grammar topics covered in this chapter -- sentence types, transitions, parallel structure, modifiers, and agreement -- represent the most commonly tested areas. Focus your practice on these patterns, as mastering them gives you the highest return on your study investment.

sections.title: Grammar Practice Strategies
sections.body:
Combine grammar study with actual TOEFL practice tasks. After learning a grammar rule, immediately apply it by writing a practice response or speaking for 60 seconds using that structure. This bridges the gap between knowing a rule and using it automatically under test conditions.

Keep an error log: every time you make a grammar mistake in a practice test, write down the incorrect sentence, the correction, and the rule it violates. Review this log weekly. Most test-takers make the same 5-10 types of errors repeatedly. Identifying and correcting your personal patterns is more effective than studying all grammar rules equally.

sections.title: Test Day Grammar Checklist
sections.body:
Before submitting any writing response, run through this quick grammar checklist: Does every sentence have a subject and a verb? Do subjects and verbs agree in number? Are verb tenses consistent and appropriate? Are lists and comparisons parallel in structure? Are modifiers placed close to the words they describe? Are transitions used correctly to show the right relationships?

For Speaking, you cannot edit after speaking, so focus on using simple, correct structures when complex ones feel risky. It is better to say "The study was important because the results were surprising" (simple and correct) than to attempt a complex sentence and lose your way mid-thought.

key_points.detail: Writing and Speaking are scored on grammar; Reading requires parsing complex sentences
Track your repeated mistakes and review them weekly for targeted improvement
Practice using grammar rules in timed writing and speaking responses
Check agreement, tenses, parallelism, modifiers, and transitions before submitting

grammar_patterns.title: Writing Proofreading Checklist
grammar_patterns.explanation: A systematic approach to checking grammar before submitting TOEFL Writing responses. Check each element in order: sentence completeness, agreement, tenses, parallelism, modifiers, and transitions.
grammar_patterns.formula: 1. Complete sentences? 2. S-V agreement? 3. Correct tenses? 4. Parallel lists? 5. Modifier placement? 6. Correct transitions?

grammar_patterns.tip: Spend at least 1 minute proofreading each writing response. Check one grammar element at a time for thoroughness.

grammar_patterns.title: Safe Grammar for Speaking
grammar_patterns.explanation: In Speaking tasks, use grammatically simple but correct structures when you are unsure about complex ones. Clear, correct simple sentences score better than broken complex sentences.
grammar_patterns.formula: Simple correct structure > Complex incorrect structure

grammar_patterns.tip: In Speaking, prioritize fluency and clarity. Use complex grammar only when you are confident it is correct.
